did.abstract: A journal describing Higinbotham's travel to Kentucky and Tennessee in February 1886. He recorded his own impressions and the opinions of local residents such as a pro-Union Louisville (Kentucky) judge, and a Nashville (Tennessee) octogenarian. Topics include the general appearance of Louisville, lack of schools in Tennessee for both whites and blacks, visit with President Polk's widow, call on Governor Bates in Nashville, the Hermitage Club, Andrew Jackson, Vanderbilt and Southern education.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Harlow N. Higinbotham was a prominent Chicago (Ill.) merchant, philanthropist partner in the firm of Marshall Field & Co., a director of the World's Columbian Exposition (later the World's Fair) of 1893, the head of the Field Museum of Natural History, and had a number of personal benefactions such as the Chicago Home for Incurables.
